title: Tags vs Conversions
goal: Understand when to use place tags vs. conversion operators.

sections.content:
Warm-up (2-3 min)

Quick review:

Conversions: se, te, ve, xe — swap x1 with another place Tags: fa, fe, fi, fo, fu — explicitly mark places

Write two ways to say "Bob receives a book from me":

  1. Using te → ?
  2. Using tags → ?

(Answers: la .bob. te dunda la cukta mi, fi la .bob. fa mi cu dunda fe la cukta)

New Material (5-7 min)

Comparing Two Systems

Both achieve the same goal — putting different arguments in prominent positions. But they differ in style and clarity.

Conversions: Pros and Cons

Pros:

  • Concise — fewer words
  • Natural once learned
  • Creates new "verbs" (te dunda = "receive")

Cons:

  • Requires mental gymnastics to track place swaps
  • Stacking conversions is confusing
  • Less explicit

Place Tags: Pros and Cons

Pros:

  • Explicit — no ambiguity
  • Any order possible
  • Easier to read for beginners
  • No mental conversion needed

Cons:

  • More verbose
  • Feels less "native Lojban" to some speakers

Side-by-Side Comparison

Goal Conversion Tags
Gift first la cukta se dunda mi la .bob. fe la cukta fa mi cu dunda fi la .bob.
Recipient first la .bob. te dunda la cukta mi fi la .bob. fa mi cu dunda fe la cukta
Price first mu no ve vecnu la karce do mi fo mu no fa mi cu vecnu fe la karce fi do

When to Use Which

Use conversions when:

  • You want a "derived verb" (te dunda = receive, se pilno = be used)
  • Brevity matters
  • You're comfortable with place swaps

Use tags when:

  • Clarity is paramount
  • You need unusual orders (not just x2 or x3 first)
  • Teaching or learning
  • Complex sentences with many places

In Practice

Most Lojban speakers use both:

  • Conversions for common derived verbs (se is very common)
  • Tags when things get complex or unusual

Key Point

Conversions are concise; tags are explicit. Use conversions for common derived verbs, tags for complex or unusual orders.

sections.content:
Practice (4-5 min)

Exercise 1: Choose Your Method

For each, write using BOTH methods:

  1. Focus on the gift: "The book is given by me to Bob."
  2. Focus on the recipient: "Alice receives a computer from Tom."
  3. Focus on the price: "100 is the price of the car to you from me."
Answers

  1. Conversion: la cukta se dunda mi la .bob. Tags: fe la cukta fa mi cu dunda fi la .bob.

  2. Conversion: la .alis. te dunda la skami la .tam. Tags: fi la .alis. fa la .tam. cu dunda fe la skami

  3. Conversion: pa no no ve vecnu la karce do mi Tags: fo pa no no fa mi cu vecnu fe la karce fi do

Exercise 2: Which is Better?

For each scenario, choose conversion or tags and explain:

  1. Quick everyday sentence: "I see the book."
  2. Complex sentence: "Using the car, from home, I go to Paris."
  3. Derived verb: "The computer is used by many people."
Answers
  1. Neither needed — mi viska la cukta (normal order)
  2. Tags — fu la karce fi la zdani fa mi cu klama fe la .paris. (complex order benefits from explicit marking)
  3. Conversion — la skami se pilno la prenu (se pilno is a natural derived verb)

sections.content:
Conversation Challenge (1-2 min)

Say aloud, using your preferred method:

  1. "Bob receives a message from me."
  2. "The car is used by Alice."
  3. "For 50, I sell a book to you."

Today's Vocab

No new gismu — focus on comparing methods.

Decision summary:

Situation Recommendation
Common derived verb Conversion
Complex order Tags
Teaching/clarity Tags
Brevity Conversion
Either works Personal preference

Summary

Conversions and tags both achieve flexible word order. Conversions are concise and create derived verbs; tags are explicit and handle any order. Use both as needed.
